{{Infobox road |marker_image=[[File:Red Coat Trail (Alberta).svg|70px]] |name=Red Coat Trail |map=RedCoatTrailMap.png |map_notes=Red Coat Trail marked in red and the [[Trans-Canada Highway]] marked in yellow |length_km=1294.3 |length_round=1 |length_ref=<ref name="Micro">{{cite map |publisher = Microsoft Corporation Redmond, Washington |title = Microsoft Streets and Tips |url = |edition = 2004 |section = |accessdate = 2008-02-25}}</ref> |established= |direction_a=West |direction_b=East |terminus_a={{jct|state=AB|Hwy|2}} near [[Fort Macleod, Alberta]] |junction= |terminus_b={{jct|state=MB|PTH|100}} near [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]] |cities=[[Lethbridge, Alberta]]; [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]] }}
[[Image:redversmountie.jpg|right|upright|thumb|200px|A Mountie statue in [[Redvers, Saskatchewan]] commemorates the founding of the Red Coat Trail along [[Saskatchewan Highway 13|SK Highway 13]] ]] The '''Red Coat Trail''' is a {{convert|1300|km|mi}} route that approximates the path taken in 1874 by the [[North-West Mounted Police]] in their quest to bring law and order to the Canadian West.<ref name="EncycOfSK">{{cite web | last= Winkel | first=James | others= | url=http://esask.uregina.ca/entry/red_coat_trail.html | title=Red Coat Trail | work=Encyclopaedia of Saskatchewan | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= Canadian Plains Research Center University of Regina | year= 2006 }} </ref><ref name="Tourism">{{cite web | url=http://www.sasktourism.com/places-to-go/road-trips/red-coat-trail | title=Red Coat Trail - Tourism Saskatchewan | work=Places to goÂ» Road Trips...Â»Red Coat | accessdate=2009-02-25 | format= | publisher= Sask Tourism | year= 2006 }} </ref>
==Travel route== A number of highways in southern [[Manitoba]], [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Alberta]] roughly follow the original route.
In Alberta, the trail follows Highways [[Alberta Highway 3|3]], [[Alberta Highway 4|4]], [[Alberta Highway 61|61]], [[Alberta Highway 889|889]], and [[Alberta Highway 501|501]].
In [[Saskatchewan]], [[Saskatchewan Highway 13|Highway 13]] is designated as Red Coat Trail. The travel corridor from the Manitoba—Saskatchewan border to [[Winnipeg]] follows [[Manitoba Highway 2|Manitoba PTH 2]].<ref group="nb" name="Winnipeg">Winnipeg: Established 1738 as [[Fort Rouge (fortification)|Fort Rouge]]; renamed 1822 [[Fort Garry]]; incorporated in 1873 as the City of [[Winnipeg]].</ref><ref name="Micro"/>
===Alberta=== Near [[Fort MacLeod, Alberta|Fort MacLeod]], the traffic volume is between 4,200 and 7,900 vehicles per day (vpd) according to the 2007 Average Annual Daily Traffic report which is quite consistent for the decade.<ref name="AB AADT">{{cite web | url=http://www.transportation.alberta.ca/2639.htm | title=Government of Alberta: Traffic Volumes at Points on the Highway | work= | accessdate=2009-03-03 | publisher= Government of Alberta | date= 1995 - 2008 }} </ref> The area is a short grass prairie [[ecosystem]] with black soils and is conducive to grain growing.<ref name="AtlasHistorical">{{cite book |editor=Kerr, D. G. G. |title=A Historical Atlas of Canada |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=776673 |accessdate=2009-03-03 |publisher=Thomas Nelson and Sons (Canada) Limted |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1960 |pages=58â61 }} </ref> Located at the junction of [[Alberta Highway 2|Hwy 2]] and the Red Coat Trail, [[Fort Macleod, Alberta|Fort Macleod]] currently has a population of over 3,000 residents<ref name="FortMacleod"/> [[Head-Smashed-In Buffalo Jump]] is a major attraction {{convert|20|mi|km}} northwest of town.<ref name="Crowsnest2">{{cite web | url=http://www.highway3.ca//communities/fortmacleod.htm | title=Hwy 3 Fort Macleod | work=Monarch, Alberta : History | accessdate=2009-03-03 | publisher= Crowsnest Highway 3 Marketing Consortium | year= 2004 }} </ref> Between Fort Macleod, and [[Lethbridge, Alberta|Lethbridge]], the Red Coat Trail runs [[concurrency (road)|concurrent]] with the [[Crowsnest Highway]] traveling through the Porcupine Hills, the Coyote Flats, and a ghost town named Pearce only marked by a railway crossing and a few farms.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> D.M. Wilson says it best, "beneath the Highway's pavement is perhaps {{convert|50|m|ft}} of [[glacial till]] consisting of sand and gravel, clays and boulder clays, humped into hills by the las continental glacier perhaps as it melted away to the northward some 11,000 years ago, overlaying some {{convert|10000|ft|m}} of sedimentary PÃºleozoic and Mesozoic strata which themselves rest on Precambrian granites. Beyond the low ridge on the far side of the cut-bank'd Oldman, an enormously rich bed of lacustrine loam began attracting settlers in the early 19-aughts and rewards so well still the agriucltural efforts of their descendants....the hills are actually longitudinal dunes of [[loess]] picked up from a nearby lakebed..."<ref name="Crowsnest">{{cite web |last=Wilson |first=Donald Malcolm | url=http://www.crowsnest-highway.ca/cgi-bin/citypage.pl?city=MONARCH | title=Crowsnest Highway | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format= | publisher= | date= 2008-03-24 }} </ref> The highway raises in elevation between the Oldman River and the Belly River watersheds and to the north of the highway is the CP Rail High Level trestle bridge of 1909.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> Currently the bridge has a well-developed trail system through the river valley and the Helen Schuler Coulee Center and Sir Alexander Galt Museum are located nearby.<ref name="Lethbridge"/> The [[Alberta Highway 3A|Hwy 3A]] alternate route carries traffic across the Oldman River on a 1997 four-lane traffic which re-routed the highway from its old course over the 1957 narrow bridge. This area features a sandstone quarry which was used for construction projects as early as 1904 and a defunct community known as Nevarre changing names to Staunton. AB Hwy 3A continues on to the village of Monarch which is just north of the confluence of the Oldman River and Belly rivers and halfway between Fort Macleod and Lethbridge. North of Monarch on [[Alberta Highway 23|Hwy 23]] and west of the village, the traffic volume is around 500 AADT, however following the Red Coat Trail into Lethbridge, the volume increases to over 5,000 vpd.<ref name="AB AADT"/> Between Monarch and Coalhurst, the Red Coat Trail is a [[Dual carriageway|twinned highway]] and between Coalhurst, and Lethbridge a multilane divided highway. West of Coalhurst, traffic volume is about 15,000 vpd, and to the east rises to approximately 18,000 vpd.<ref name="AB AADT"/> Oil, flax, wheat and sugar beets are the staples of the agricultural economy supplemented by gas and oil in 1974 which replaced the sugar beet harvests.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> The [[city]] of [[Lethbridge, Alberta|Lethbridge]], is locagted at the junction of [[Alberta Highway 4|AB Hwy 4]], [[Alberta Highway 5|Hwy 5]] and [[Alberta Highway 3|Hwy 3]].<ref name="Lethbridge">{{cite web | url=http://www.highway3.ca//communities/lethbridge.htm | title=Hwy 3 Letthbridge | accessdate=2009-03-03 | publisher= Crowsnest Highway 3 Marketing Consortium | year= 2004 }} </ref> Travel along the Red Coat Trail corridor leaves Hwy 3 and continues on Hwy 4 south east towards [[Stirling, Alberta|Stirling]], with a traffic volume around 5,500 vpd. Whence at Stirling, the Red Coat Trail travel corridor leaves Hwy 4 and now continues east along [[Alberta Highway 61|Hwy 61]] towards the small hamlet of [[Wrentham, Alberta|Wrentham]] at the junction of [[Alberta Highway 36|Hwy 36]]. Between Stirling and Wrentham the traffic volume declines to an AADT of about 550 vpd on a secondary undivided paved highway.<ref name="AB AADT"/> The Red Coat Trail runs parallel and north of the Etzikom Coulee and Crow Indian Lake and to the north of the Red Coat Trail are the Chin Lakes and the Chin Reservoir.<ref name="Chin">{{cite web | url=http://www.fishalberta.com/02Season/Jensen/chin.htm | title=Chin Reservoir | work= | accessdate=2009-03-03 | publisher= | date= }} </ref> Coulees are meltwater channels produced by glacier meltoff forming long river valleys. A number of these coulees are dry or almost dry, and some such as the Chin Lakes have been formed by the Chin Reservoir. The weather of southeast Alberta is warmer than the rest of the province, with lower annual precipitation creating a grassland ecoregion.<ref name="Etzikom">{{cite web | url=http://sunsite.ualberta.ca/Projects/Alberta-Lakes/characteristics1.php | title=Atlas of Alberta Lakes | work=Department of Biological Sciences | accessdate=2009-03-03 | format= | publisher= | date= 2004-2005 }} </ref> At the junction of the Red Coat Trail and [[Alberta Highway 877|Hwy 877]] is the small hamlet of [[Skiff, Alberta|Skiff]], population 10, with a declining AADT between 350 to 400 vpd.<ref name="AB AADT"/> The village of [[Foremost, Alberta|Foremost]] is located at the junction with [[Alberta Highway 879|Hwy 879]] near {{convert|40|mi|km|adj=on}} park, and Writing-on-Stone Provincial Park.<ref name="forty">{{cite web |others=The Fyke's | url=http://www.40milepark.com/ | title=40 Mile Park & Recreation Area | accessdate=2009-03-03 | format= | publisher= | date= January 23, 2009 }} </ref><ref name="formeost">{{cite web | url=http://www.foremostalberta.com/tourism.aspx?pg=writingonstone | title=Foremost, Alberta | accessdate=2009-03-03 |work=Writing-on-Stone Provincial Park | format= | publisher= | date= January 23, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref> [[Etzikom, Alberta|Etzikom]] on the intersection of the Red Coat Trail and [[Alberta Highway 855|AB Hwy 855]] features the Etzikom Museum and the Canadian National Historical Windmill Center.<ref name="formeost">{{cite web | url=http://www.foremostalberta.com/tourism.aspx?pg=etzikom | title=Foremost, Alberta | accessdate=2009-03-03 |work=Etzikom Museum and Historical Windmill Center | format= | publisher= | date= January 23, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref> [[Orion, Alberta|Orion]], a small hamlet with a population of less than 10 residents, is located at the intersection of [[Alberta Highway 887|AB Hwy 887]] and the Red Coat Trail. The traffic between Orion and the Saskatchewan border is very low averaging between 70 to 100 vpd.<ref name="AB AADT"/> [[Manyberries, Alberta|Manyberries]] is located at the eastern terminus of [[Alberta Highway 61|AB Hwy 61]] travel on the Red Coat Trail continues south on [[Alberta Highway 889|Hwy 889]] a secondary connector road to meet with [[Alberta Highway 501|Hwy 501]], a secondary gravel highway to the Alberta—Saskatchewan border.
===Saskatchewan=== {{main|Saskatchewan Highway 13}} There are 36 communities along the {{convert|676|km|mi}} of the Saskatchewan portion of the Red Coat Trail which would be one approximately every {{convert|20|km|mi}} apart, and there are 59 at grade intersections with primary and secondary highways which would be a junction approximately every {{convert|10|km|mi}}. The highway volume beginning in Saskatchewan along the Red Coat Trail about 45 vpd on a class 4 gravel highway.<ref name="Class">{{cite web | url = http://www.highways.gov.sk.ca/adx/aspx/adxGetMedia.aspx?DocID=227,81,1,Documents&MediaID=1500&Filename=2007-08+Road+Classification.pdf | title = 2007-08 Road Classification Map 2007-08 Road Classification.pdf ( 424.5 KB ) | accessdate = 2009-02-08 | year = 2007 | format =Have to rename file as a pdf to open and view | work =Highways and Infrastructure About Highways/Saskatchewan Maps | publisher = Saskatchewan Government }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="HwyVolume">{{cite web | url =http://www.highways.gov.sk.ca/adx/aspx/adxGetMedia.aspx?DocID=227,81,1,Documents&MediaID=1386&Filename=trafficvolume-2007.pdf | title =Highway Traffic Volume Map trafficvolume-2007.pdf ( 1.5 MB ) | accessdate = 2009-02-08 | year = 2007 | format =Have to rename file as a pdf to open and view | work =Highways and Infrastructure About Highways/Saskatchewan Maps | publisher = Saskatchewan Government }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="Surface type">{{cite web |last=Lau |first=Tony | url =http://www.highways.gov.sk.ca/adx/aspx/adxGetMedia.aspx?DocID=227,81,1,Documents&MediaID=1461&Filename=surface.pdf | title =2007-08 Saskatchewan Highway Surface Type surface.pdf ( 302 KB ) | date = 2007-08 | format =DHT internet map (Have to rename file as a pdf to open and view) | work =Highways and Infrastructure About Highways/Saskatchewan Maps | publisher = Saskatchewan Government }}</ref>
SK Hwy 615 provides access north to [[Fort Walsh|Fort Walsh National Historic Park]] and the highest point of land in Saskatchewan. Travel is mainly east through the province of Saskatchewan on the Red Coat Trail which is continuous on SK Hwy 13 which is a secondary paved undivided highway until [[Weyburn, Saskatchewan|Weyburn]]. It is at the [[Consul, Saskatchewan|Consul]] intersection of highways that the Red Coat Trail changes to a [[Pavement_(material)#Thin_membrane_surface|thin membrane surface]] undivided highway where the traffic volume increases to about 80 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/> Travel continues north east until the junction with [[Saskatchewan Highway 21|SK Hwy 21]] which provides access to [[Cypress Hills Provincial Park]] and [[Maple Creek, Saskatchewan|Maple Creek]]. The Red Coat Trail continues east after this intersection on a class 3 [[Pavement_(material)#Granular_pavements|granular pavement]] highway and traffic here increases to an AADT of 270 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/> There is a junction with [[Saskatchewan Highway 18|SK Hwy 18]] before the highway turns north again to arrive at the intersection of [[Saskatchewan Highway 614|SK Hwy 614]] and the town of [[Eastend, Saskatchewan|Eastend]], which has the nickname Dino Country where a [[Tyrannosaurus|''Tyrannosauraus rex'']] was discovered spawning the T. rex Discovery Centre.<ref name="eastend">{{cite web | url=http://www.dinocountry.com/ | title=Dino Country, Eastend Saskatchewan home of Scotty the T Rex ... | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format= | publisher= Tangle Media | date= 1987-2000 }} </ref><ref name="dino">{{cite web | url=http://www.dinocountry.com/?s=263&p=263&0=263 | title=Dino Country, Eastend Saskatchewan home of Scotty the T Rex Canada's most complete Tryannosaurus fossil find and the hunting capital of Southwest Saskatchewan. | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format= | publisher= Tangle Media | date= 1987-2000 }} </ref> A number of [[Fauna_of_Saskatchewan#Ancient_fauna_-_paleontology|ancient fauna]] [[paleontology|paleontological]] dig sites exist in southern Saskatchewan.<ref name="Royal">{{cite web | title = Royal Saskatchewan Museum: Publications: Earth Sciences | work = | publisher = Royal Saskatchewan Museum. | year = 2009 | url = http://www.royalsaskmuseum.ca/research/publications/earth_sciences.shtml#espub6 | format = | doi = | accessdate =2009-01-25 }} </ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Prothero |first= Donald R. |coauthors=Robert J. Emry |title=The Terrestrial Eocene-Oligocene Transition in North America |url=http://books.google.com/?id=tCwwlEmSdJkC&pg=PA240&lpg=PA240&dq=Calf+Creek+Local+Fauna |format=Digitized online by Google books |accessdate=2009-01-25 |edition=illustrated |year=1996 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521433878, 9780521433877 |pages=244â255 |chapter=Eocene-Oligocene Faunas of the Cypress Hills Formation, Saskatchewan by John E. Storer |quote=*Outline drawing of part of Swift Current Plateau south of Swift Current showing place names and sources of Eocene-Oligocene mammalian paleofaunas. All ranges west of the [[106th meridian west|Third Meridian]]. 1. Swift Current Creek Local Fauna 2. Lac Pelletier Lower Fauna 3. Lac Pelletier Upper Fauna 5. Simmie Local Fauana 9. Blumenort Local Fauna *Outline drawing of Eastend area, Cypress Hills of southwestern Saskatchewan showing place names and sources of Eocene-Oligocene mammalian paleofaunas. All ranges west of the Third Meridian. 4. Southfork Local Fauna Chadronian 6. Calf Creek Local Fauna, Chadronian 7. Carnagh Local Fauna, Chadronian. 8. Irish Spring Local Fauna Anxiety Butte. Orellian. 14. Rodent Hill Local Fauna Whitneyan; 15. Anxiety Butte, Whitneyan: 16. Kealey Springs Local Fauna, early Arikareean; 17. Anxiety Butte, late Arikareean. }} </ref>
This area of the Red Coat Trail receives an increase of traffic wherein about 300 vpd travel the Red Coat Trail east of Eastend and over 650 vpd east of town resulting in an upgrade to [[asphalt concrete]] [[Road surface|road construction]].<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/> The traffic volume entering Shaunavon is about 600 vpd, and the AADT increases to over 1,000 vpd heading north on the SK Hwy 37 and Red Coat Trail concurrency. SK Hwy 37 provides access to the town of [[Gull Lake, Saskatchewan|Gull Lake]] and in {{convert|9.4|km|mi}}, the Red Coat Trail turns east on a thin membrane surface class 2 highway bearing between 150 to 250 vpd.<ref name="Class"/><ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/> The Red Coat Trail is upgraded to a class 5 granular pavement as traffic can reach a high of 530 vpd east of this [[Saskatchewan Highway 4|SK Hwy 4]] intersection.<ref name="Class"/><ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/> To the north west of the [[Saskatchewan Highway 58|SK Hwy 58]] junction is Thomson Lake which is a man made lake used for recreational and reservoir purposes becoming the first regional park of Saskatchewan. [[Lafleche, Saskatchewan|Lafleche]] at the junction with [[Saskatchewan Highway 58|SK Hwy 58]], and east of this junction the AADT increases to over 600 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title =Thomson Lake local regional park | date = | year = | url =http://www.thomsonlake.com/ | accessdate = 2007-05-15 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title =Thomson Lake regional park Lafleche, Saskatchewan | date = | year = | url =http://www.canadianrooms.com/mem/6520.htm | accessdate = 2007-05-15 | postscript = <!--None--> |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070127035249/http://www.canadianrooms.com/mem/6520.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-01-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title =Lafleche Parks & Gardens: Parks & Gardens in Lafleche, Saskatchewan | date = | year = | url =http://saskatchewan.worldweb.com/SoutheastRegion/Lafleche/SightsAttractions/ParksGardens/ | accessdate = 2007-05-15 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> The Louis Pierre Gravel National Historic Marker commemorates history at the north end of SK Hwy 58, and the Cripple Creek Provincial Historic Marker is located at the junction with the Red Coat Trail (the southern terminus of SK Hwy 58]].<ref name="RC REDA">{{cite web | url=http://www.redcoatreda.com/html/industry/tourism.html | title=Red Coat Regional Economic Development Authority INC.(REDA) - Tourism | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= | year= 2008 }} </ref>
The terrain of the Missouri Coteau features low hummocky, undulating, rolling hills, potholes, and grasslands. This physiographic region of Saskatchewan is the uplands Missouri Coteau, a part of the Great Plains Province or Alberta Plateau Region which extends across the south east corner of the province of Saskatchewan.<ref>{{Cite document | last =Richards | first =J.H. | author-link = | last2 =Fung | first2 =K.I. | author2-link = | title =Atlas of Saskatchewan | place=Saskatoon | publisher =Modern Press | year =1969 | location =University of Saskatchewan | volume = | edition = | url = | doi = | id = | postscript =<!--None--> }}</ref> [[Saskatchewan Highway 2|SK Hwy 2]] and [[Saskatchewan Highway 717|SK Hwy 717]] come together at the town of [[Assiniboia, Saskatchewan|Assinibioia]]. Just to the west of Assiniboia the traffic volume increases to about 1,000 vpd and to the east of town, the volume decreases to about 800 vpd and the majority of the highway is class 3 granular pavement.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="assiniboia">{{cite web | url=http://www.assiniboia.net/ | title=Town of Assiniboia | Heart of the Golden South! | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format= | publisher= Town of Assiniboia and Assiniboia Economic Development Authority. | year= 2008 }} </ref>
The intersection with [[Saskatchewan Highway 621|SK Hwy 621 north]] is passed before arriving at the [[city]] of [[Weyburn, Saskatchewan|Weyburn]] which is on the intersection of [[Saskatchewan Highway 35|SK Hwy 35]], [[Saskatchewan Highway 39|SK Hwy 39]], the [[CanAm Highway]]. [[Weyburn, Saskatchewan|Weyburn]], the opportunity city, has also been dubbed the ''Soo Line City'' due its connection with [[Chicago]] on the Soo Line of the [[Canadian Pacific Railway|Canadian Pacific Railway CPR]].<ref name="weyburn">{{cite web | last = Weyburn Writer's Association | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Hey, seeds! | work = Our Roots Nos Racines | publisher = University of Calgary, UniversitÃ© Laval | year =2006 | url = http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=545038 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-15}}</ref> The city of 9,433 people is situated on [[Saskatchewan Highway 35|SK Hwy 35]], SK Hwy 39, and SK Hwy 13. absorbed the small towns of Exon and Converge into the city.<ref name="stats">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =2006 Community Profiles - Census Subdivision | work =Statistics Canada | publisher = Government of Canada | date = 04/02/2008 | url = http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/profiles/community/Details/Page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=4702047&Geo2=PR&Code2=47&Data=Count&SearchText=Weyburn&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&B1=All&Custom= | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-15}}</ref><ref name="canada">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Canadian Rural Partnership - Rural Development - Public - Private Partnerships in Rural and Northern Canada Study - Appendix C - List of Projects | work = Government of Canada | publisher = | date =2005-09-26 | url = http://ndpcaucus.sk.ca/topics/read.php3/423.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Adamson | first = J | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Saskatchewan, Canada, Rand McNally 1924 Indexed Pocket Map Tourists' and Shippers' Guide< | work =Online Historical Map Digitization Project | publisher = Ancestry / Rootsweb | date = 5 November 2003 | url = http://www.cfib.ca/legis/sask/pdf/sk0260.pdf |format=PDF| doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-15}}</ref> Weyburn is located astride the Williston geological Basin which contains oil deposits, and several wells operate in the vicinity.<ref name="canada"/> There are roadside attractions featured here such as a large Lighthouse water tower, wheat sheaves and Prairie Lily.<ref name="Weyburn">{{cite web | url=http://www.milebymile.com/main/Canada/Saskatchewan/State_6_2/Canada_Saskatchewan_road_map_travel_guides.html | title=Saskatchewan Road Map RV Travel Guide: #6 Canada / United States Border to Regina | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= Mile By Mile Media | year=2007 }} </ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Donnan | first =Richard | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Lighthouse Water Tower Weyburn, Saskatchewan | work = | publisher = LARGE CANADIAN ROADSIDE ATTRACTIONS | date = 1999 - 2006 | url = http://www.roadsideattractions.ca/weyburn.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2008-02-15}}</ref> Weyburn is situated near the upper delta of the {{convert|470|mi|km}} long Souris River. The Souris River continues southeast through North Dakota eventually meeting the Assiniboine River in Manitoba.<ref name="weyburn"/>
The Red Coat Trail is primarily ashpalt concrete between SK Hwy 6 and SK Hwy 47 where traffic volume reaches about 1,450 vpd east of Weyburn, and over 3,500 vpd within the city on this class 2 highway.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/> There is a short stretch of granular pavement before [[Saskatchewan Highway 9|SK Hwy 9]] where the traffic volume falls to about 1,700 vpd, rising to about 2,400 vpd near [[Carlyle, Saskatchewan|Carlyle]].<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/>
The town of Carlyle is at the intersection with SK Hwy 9, which provides access north to [[Moose Mountain Provincial Park]] and [[Cannington Manor Provincial Historic Park]]. Before the [[Manitoba]] border the Red Coat Trail is granular pavement with traffic volume below 1,000 vpd.<ref name="HwyVolume"/><ref name="Surface type"/> [[Manor, Saskatchewan|Manor]] on [[Saskatchewan Highway 603|SK Hwy 603]], Antler River, [[Wauchope, Saskatchewan|Wauchope]] on [[Saskatchewan Highway 601|SK Hwy 601]], [[Redvers, Saskatchewan|Redvers]] on [[Saskatchewan Highway 9|SK Hwy 9]], Gainsborough Creek and finally [[Antler, Saskatchewan|Antler]] on [[Saskatchewan Highway 600|SK Hwy 600]] are the last localities in Saskatchewan before Manitoba.<ref name="RVTimes">{{cite web | url=http://www.rvtimes.com/arch/RVT88HTML/88redcoattrail.html | title=RV Times #88 - Canada's magazine for RVers, Camping and Vacationing | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= Sheila Jones Publishing Ltd. | date= 1987-2000 }} </ref>
===Manitoba=== {{main|Manitoba Highway 2}} In Manitoba 19 communities populate the Red Coat Trail between the Saskatchewan border and [[Winnipeg]]. There are also 33 at grade intersections with numbered provincial highways and roads on this {{convert|349.2|km|mi}} portion of the Red Coat Trail in Manitoba.<ref name="Cypress River">{{cite web | url=http://www.cypressriver.ca/home.htm | title=Cypress River Manitoba Canada for your next vacation | work=Welcome to Cypress River | accessdate=2009-02-23 | publisher= | date= February 23, 2009 }} </ref><ref name="Kincaid">{{cite book |others=Kincaid History Book Committee |title=The History of Kincaid, Saskatchewan and area, 1909-1980. |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=4130700 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter= }} </ref>
==History== Early travelers had two rivers to ford without bridge or ferry between Fort MacLeod and Coal Banks, one at Monarch and the other at Coal Banks.<ref group="nb" name="Lethbridge">Lethbridge post office was so named in 1885, previously named Coal Banks or Coalbanks. Lethbridge also had other names such as steep banks, the place of black rocks, painted rock, red painted rock, medicine stone, where they slaughtered the Cree, the coal Bank, and Sheran's Ferry crossing amongst others.</ref><ref name="Nineteenth"/> Pioneers travelled the pioneer trails across the grasslands during the 19th century created by travellers, first nations and fur traders. The grasslands area of today was still forested in the 19th century and land would need to be cleared and broken for agricultural homesteads and roads.<ref name="Tiger Hills">{{cite book |others=Treherne Area History Committee |title=Tiger Hills to the Assiniboine |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=776673 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |pages=11 to 13 }} </ref> In the 19th century southern Saskatchewan was known as an extension of the ''Greater Yellow Grass Marsh''.<ref name="canada"/> The Dominion Land surveyors marked the quarter sections of Manitoba in 1874â1875 and of Saskatchewan in 1881 and homesteaders began tilling their homesteads and fencing their quarter-sections.<ref name="Tiger Hills"/><ref name="Carlyle"/> Travel transferred from prairie trail to road allowances set by the surveyors. Rural municipalities set road bosses and crews to grade the roads and to fill in the low areas. Walking plows would till the soil that was to be moved by the fresnoes, which was a scraper pulled with two horses. Those who worked on roads would have lowered taxes. Later crews would work with four-horse scrapers followed by crawler tractors which could pull even larger graders and scrapers.<ref name="Carlyle">{{cite book |others=Carlyle and District Historical Society |title=Prairie Trails to Blacktop Carlyle and District, 1882-1982 |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3595878 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |pages=53 to 63 }} </ref> The rural municipality would work out a system of road work for the various ratepayers, and pathmasters or road crew foremen were appointed to oversee the statute labour conducted. Road sections were constructed from one stopping place to the next, where a stopping place was a settler's home who had built additional accommodation for travelers. Ferries were primarily used to cross rivers and creeks, and these often afforded stopping places.<ref name="Tiger Hills"/> Approximately 1890 the piers were set for the first highway bridge across the [[Oldman River|Belly River]].<ref group="nb">The current name for the Belly River is the Oldman River</ref><ref name="Nineteenth"/> The first car in Alberta was owned by F.W. Cochrane of Macleod in 1901.<ref name="Macleod">{{cite book |others=Macleod Sketch Club |title=The story of Macleod |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=865041 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter=Macleod Memoirs }} </ref> These first electric and steam driven cars were set with a high clearance and were able to travel a prairie trail and follow in ruts, soon cars were gasoline powered.<ref name="Carlyle"/> Lethbridge was subject to flooding in the early 20th century, the years 1902, 1907 and 1908, uplifting houses, barns, bridges and trees.<ref name="Nineteenth"/> During the May 1902 flooding a house floating in the river removed the east span of the bridge which was under repair when the June 1902 flood removed the centre span of the bridge. The Territorial Department of Public Works decided upon a steel bridge set upon concrete piers and received a $50.000 grant for construction from the Dominion Government. The floor of the bridge was wood planking across the {{convert|16|ft|m}} wide bridge.<ref name="The Bend"/><ref group="nb" name="Lethbridge"/> To the north of the Red Coat Trail is the [[Canadian Pacific Railway|Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR)]] trestle bridge or the CP Rail High Level Bridge. This {{convert|1891|ft|m}} long, {{convert|150|ft|m}} high [[trestle bridge]] across the Oldman River was constructed between 1908 and 1909.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> In 1910, the Lethbridge Board of Trade was claiming that the government maintains the main roads and bridges and that the roads were good with few hills. The speed limit of this era for automobiles was 25 miles per hour, yet settlers still used horse and automobile for transport.<ref name="LethbridgeFacts">{{cite book |others=Lethbridge (Alta.). Board of Trade |title=Facts for the settler about the Lethbridge District : sunny southern Alberta |url=http://www.nosracines.ca/e/toc.aspx?id=4139 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1910 |publisher=Lethbridge, Alberta: Daily Herald Presses, |chapter=Roads and Bridges }} </ref> In 1910, travel across the prairies was by rail, of which there were five branches of rail line branching out from Lethbridge, a divisional and terminal point. The Weyburn branch of the [[Canadian Pacific Railway|Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR)]] was under construction in 1910 as well, which eventually connected Winnipeg and Lethbridge.<ref name="LethbridgePotential">{{cite book |last=McQueen, |first= F. |title=Lethbridge : a city of potentialities |url=http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=329883 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1911 |publisher=Lethbridge, Alberta: Daily Herald Presses, |chapter=How Has Lethbridge Attained its Pre-eminence? }} </ref><ref name="LethbridgeRail">{{cite book |others=Lethbridge (Alta.) Board of Trade |url=http://www.nosracines.ca/e/toc.aspx?id=4138 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1907 |publisher=Lethbridge, Alberta: Southern Alberta News |chapter=As a Railway Centre |title=Lethbridge:a railway centre with the mineral resources of Pittsburg and the agriculture territory of Minneapolis }} </ref> In 1910, taxes were set at six and a quarter cents per acre and homesteaders could work on the road crew to help with this payment. A driver and one team of horses could earn [[Canada dollar|C$]]5.00 per day, and a driver with two teams of horses could earn $7.00 for a day's labour, where a day would be nine hours in duration.<ref name="redvers">{{cite book |others=Celebrate Saskatchewan Committee (Redvers), Golden Age Centre (Redvers, Sask.) |title=Redvers, 75 Years Live |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=1043816 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter=Rural Municipality of Antler No. 61 |pages= }} </ref> It was not until 1912 that the Board of Highway Commissioners was created to authorise road grants for improvements.<ref name="Carlyle"/> One of the first traffic bridges across the Oldman River near Monarch, Alberta, was erected in 1913.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> Red shale can still be seen of the Taylor coal mine (1916â1925) constructed in the upper river bank north of the Lethbridge, Ab traffic bridge.<ref name="The Bend">{{cite book |others=West Lethbridge History Book Society |title=The Bend: A History of West Lethbridge |url=http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=914543 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1907 |publisher=Lethbridge, Alberta: Southern Alberta News |pages=5, 9, 10 }} </ref> By the early 1920s most residents had cars for transport.<ref name="Carlyle"/> In the 1920s roads were gravelled, gravel loaded by shovel, and hauled with horse and wagon, so that automobiles would not become mired down in mud in the low-lying areas. However, the gravel was too thick, and loose gravel meant horses needed to be shoed and cars would careen wildly over the road, and so therefore the grass trail alongside the road was used instead. The Department of Public Works fixed this problem by mixing clay with the gravel. This era was followed by four-horse teams pulling a sulky plow across the roads, eliminating ruts and forming a hard and level surface to drive upon.<ref name="The Bend"/> The 1920s were indeed years of road work; however in these pioneering days there was little background or guidelines to go by. Early road work consisted of levelling roads and filling in low spots which would collect water to make travel easier by the first automobiles. Road ways and road allowances could either be purchased or leased from the homesteader who was proving up that farmland. A challenge to rural municipality councilors was the removal of rocks from the road allowance. Government grants were set out for road construction where the ratepayers of the rural municipality came together in road camps for improvements and there were also Road Day Competitions held. The road would divert around sloughs, hills, and other diversions to make the travel easier for horse and cart.<ref name="The Bend">{{cite book |last=Mehain |first=Anne |others=Limerick Historical Society |title=Prairie Trails and Pioneer Tales : R.M. of Stonehenge #73 |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/toc.aspx?id=4891 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |year= 1982 |publisher=Limerick, Saskatchewan: Limerick Historical Society, |pages=11, 12 }} </ref> In 1921 Highway 13 was graded up through the low areas around the Carlyle area. A foreman could earn between [[Canada dollar|C$]]6.00 and 7.00 for a day, a graderman could earn between $4.50 and 5.00 per day, labourers in 1921 would earn $4.00 to 450 per day. A driver of a single team of horses could earn between $7.50 and 88.00 per day, and a driver with a double team of horses could earn up to $10.00 to 10.50 in a day.<ref name="Carlyle"/> The Relief Roadwork Program of 1928 which initiated roadwork on Highway 13. Those local residents with four horses and a grader initially maintained the highway. During the depression years of the dirty thirties, roadwork continued and the highways were widened, gravelled and paved.<ref name="cadillac"/> Gravel was laid on highways in the early 1930s which alleviated being mired in the mud during rainy weather; however during dry weather, gravel roads produced great quantities of dust, reducing visibility.<ref name="Tiger Hills"/><ref name="Carlyle"/> In 1930, the Manitoba provincial government constructed Highway 2 with hard surfacing to follow.<ref name="Tiger Hills"/> Road crew wages changed to hourly in 1932, where a foreman of a road crew could now earn 35 cents an hour, a man with a two-horse team 45 to 50 cents an hour and a driver with four horses could earn 65 to 70 cents an hour, and labourers could now bring in 25 cents an hour. In Saskatchewan, [[Carlyle, Sasaktchean|Carlyle]] was established for example as the area headquarters which supervised six Department of Highway road crews along Highway 13. The crews would remove snow and ice during winter months, and during the summer months conduct road allowance mowing, ensure drainage, attend to sign and guard rail repair.<ref name="Carlyle"/> During the 1940s Pearce, Alberta, was home to a CPR station, village, and the British Commonseath Air Training Program featuring the No. 36 Elementary Flying School.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> In 1943, tractor operator scrapers termed tumble bugs, were available to rural municipalities. After [[World War II]], rural municipalities equipment such as crawler tractors, scrapers and graders could be purchased.<ref name="redvers"/> As of 1949 the early steel bridge across the Oldman River in Lethbridge was replaced.<ref name="The Bend"/> Winter still proved a challenge in the 1950s and roads could be blocked. bombardiers, and early passenger ski doo could be employed for emergency transportation.<ref name="Carlyle"/> In 1952, a general standard was established wherein the provincial government paid 60% and the rural municipalities the remainder for road planning and improvements. Bridges over {{convert|100|ft|m}} in length would be paid entirely by the province; shorter bridge costs would be jointly shared.<ref name="Carlyle"/> MB Hwy 2 was constructed to the modern highway able to carry high-speed vehicles, and steel culverts have replaced the early wooded bridges.<ref name="Tiger Hills"/> A very narrow traffic bridge was constructed in 1957 across the Oldman near Monarch, Alberta, replacing the 1913 predecessor, and currently gives a route to cyclers while the truckers and vehicular traffic currently use the new four-lane bridge.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> It wasn't until the 1960s that these gravel highways were oiled to reduce the dust clouds; however these oiled surfaces could not bear heavy loads of commercial traffic.<ref name="Carlyle"/> In 1968, the Department of Highways was established in the town of Cadillac.<ref name="cadillac">{{cite book |others=Cadillac and District History Book Association |title=Cadillac : prairie heritage |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=750166 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter= |pages=27 }} </ref><ref name="dry">{{cite book |last=Jones |first= David C. |title=We'll all be Buried Down Here : the Prairie Dryland Disaster, 1917-1926 |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=245971 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter= |pages=27 }} </ref> During the 1970s, the [[Saskatchewan Highway 13|SK Hwy 13]] was extended between [[Eastend, Saskatchewan|Eastend]] and the Alberta border as part of the Red River Trail corridor.<ref name="Range">{{cite book |others=Eastend History Society |title=Range Riders and Sodbusters |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=2881575 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1907 |publisher= |pages=36 }} </ref> It was also in the 1970s that the highway was paved to withstand heavy loads as potash was being mined in [[Esterhazy, Saskatchewan|Esterhazy]] and the oil highways were breaking under the added weight.<ref name="Carlyle"/> "Extensive flood control programs have created reservoirs, parks and waterfowl centres along the Souris River." near Weyburn, Sk.<ref name="canada"/> Between 1988 and 1995, the Rafferty-Alameda Project was constructed to alleviate spring flooding problems created by the Souris River.<ref name="water">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Water Control - Saskatchewan Dams and Reservoirs | work = Saskatchewan Watershed Authority | publisher = | date = | url =http://www.swa.ca/WaterManagement/DamsAndReservoirs.asp?type=RaffertyAlameda# | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-15}}</ref> The Red Coat Trail travels across the Oldman River near Monarch Alberta on a pre-stressed four-lane concrete bridge which was completed in 1997.<ref name="Crowsnest"/> "Highway 13, also known as the Red Coat Trail, has seen a significant amount of upgrading in recent years. The transformation of this highway between the Manitoba border and Cadillac, SK from a thin membrane surface (TMS) to a paved standard is nearing completion. In the 2004 construction season, {{convert|39|km|mi}} will be improved; in 2003 almost {{convert|70|km|mi}}was upgraded or resurfaced; and in the 2002 construction season {{convert|70|km|mi}} of Highway 13 was upgraded or resurfaced."<ref name="Viceroy">{{cite web | url=http://www.gov.sk.ca/news?newsId=852addaa-1364-4e7f-9251-8b2df577a249 | title=Improving Highway 13 near Viceroy | work=Highways and Transportation: About Government/News Releases/ | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format= | publisher= Government of Saskatchewan | date=August 2004 }} </ref>
==Red Coat Trail history== {{main|Royal Canadian Mounted Police}} Sir [[John A. Macdonald]] read the bill to create the North-West Mounted Police in 1873, which was passed in May of that year. Recruitment of men for the police force began in September 1873 and they assembled at [[Emerson, Manitoba|Fort Dufferin, Manitoba]].<ref group="nb" name="Dufferin">Fort Dufferin, Manitoba is now at the location of [[Emerson, Manitoba]]</ref> The [[CanadaâUnited_States_border#History|border]] between the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] was surveyed in 1872.<ref name="Meyronne Memories">{{cite book |last=Day |first=Clifford |others=Mrs. M. H. Little, |title=Meyronne Memories, 1908-1967 |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=1067380 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |chapter=The Story of the Royal Northwest Mounted Police |year=1907 |publisher=Lethbridge, Alberta: Southern Alberta News |pages=4 }} </ref> On July 8, 1874, these trained men were despatched on their western journey.<ref name="Meyronne Memories"/><ref name="Brief">{{cite book |others=Short Grass Historical Society |title=Long Shadows : a history of shortgrass country |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=272015 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter=Royal Northwest Mounted Police }} </ref> There is a museum and the 1884 NWMP Barracks Site at Fort Macleod which preserves the NWMP history at the Fort, supplemented by a RCMP musical ride which is held yearly in commemoration.<ref name="FortMacleod">{{cite web | url=http://www.fortmacleod.com/visiting/ | title=Visiting Fort Macleod, in southwestern Alberta, Canada | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format= | publisher= | date= 1987-2000 }} </ref> Healy and Hamilton built Fort Whoop Up {{convert|8|mi|km}} miles from the current location of Lethbridge near the confluence of the St. Mary and Belly Rivers. (Today the location of Fort Whoop Up is signified by a historical cairn marker.) Colonel Macleod of the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police|Royal Northwest Mounted Police (RNWMP)]] presented Healy and Hamilton with an offer to purchase Fort Whoop Up which they declined.{{#tag:ref|The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) was formed in 1920 by the merger of the Royal Northwest Mounted Police (RNWMP, founded 1873) with the [[Dominion Police]] (founded 1868). The North-West Mounted Police became the Royal Northwest Mounted Police after 1904.<ref name="Glenbow">{{cite web |title=Fort Dufferin, Manitoba. |work=The Glenbow Museum > Archives Photographs Search Results |url=http://ww2.glenbow.org/search/archivesPhotosResults.aspx?XC=/search/archivesPhotosResults.aspx&TN=IMAGEBAN&AC=QBE_QUERY&RF=WebResults&DL=0&RL=0&NP=255&MF=WPEngMsg.ini&MR=10&QB0=AND&QF0=File+number&QI0=NA-361-23&DF=WebResultsDetails |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter= }} </ref>|group="nb"}}<ref name="Brief">{{cite book |others=Lethbridge Herald |title=Lethbridge: Alberta's Golden Jubilee |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3523051 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter=Brief Look Into the Past }} </ref> RNWMP were established at Coal Banks in 1885 forming K Division under the command of Superintendent A.R. McDonnell. This site in the Porcupine Hills was the coal mining site of Lethbridge.<ref>{{cite book |others=Lethbridge Herald |title=Lethbridge: Alberta's Golden Jubilee |url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=3523051 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |chapter=Policing the Plains }} </ref> The Red Coats of 1874 had the option to settle on ranches following their three-year term with the RNWMP.<ref name="Nineteenth">{{cite book |last=Peat |first= Annie Laurie Stafrord |title= Nineteenth Century Lethbridge |url=http://www.nosracines.ca/e/page.aspx?id=874181 |format=Digitised online by Our Roots Nos Racines |accessdate=2009-02-24 |publisher=Lethbridge, Alberta: Historical Society of Alberta, |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1978 |pages=33, 38, 47 and 49 |chapter=Lethbridge's Beginning }} </ref> [[Grasslands National Park]] near Ponteix, Sk features NWMP trail markers amidst the Killdeer Badlands.<ref name="ponteix">{{cite web | url=http://www.townofponteix.com/ | title=Town of Ponteix | work= | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format= | publisher= | date= 1987-2000 }} </ref><ref name="grasslands">{{cite web | url=http://www.pc.gc.ca/pn-np/sk/grasslands/natcul/natcul5_e.asp | title=Parks Canada - Grasslands National Park of Canada |work=National Parks > Grasslands National Park of Canada | accessdate=2009-02-25 | format= | publisher= Government of Canada | date= 2008-10-22 }} </ref> Wood Mountain Post was established in 1874 to reduce cattle rustling, whisky trading, which was completed post haste, and the NWMP post closed in 1875. Following his victory against the U.S. cavalry in the 1876 [[Battle of the Little Bighorn]], Sitting Bull and about 5,000 of his followers sought sanctuary in the [[Wood Mountain, Saskatchewan|Wood Mountain, Sk]] area.<ref name="Grass-lands">{{cite web |last= Yanko |first= Dave | url=http://www.virtualsk.com/current_issue/grasslands.html | title=Virtual Saskatchewan - Grasslands National Park | accessdate=2009-02-25 | publisher= | date= 1997-2007) }} </ref> [[James Morrow Walsh|Superintendent James Walsh]] from [[Fort Walsh]] left the [[Cypress Hills]] area to talk to Sitting Bull. 22 NWMP police officer accompanied by Walsh set up a new Wood Mountain detachment, Walsh remained here with the men until his transfer to [[Fort Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan|Fort Qu'Appelle]] in 1880.<ref name="Woodmountain">{{cite web |last= Yanko |first= Dave | url=http://www.saskbiz.ca/communityprofiles/CommunityProfile.Asp?CommunityID=734 | title=Wood Mountain |work=Sask Biz | accessdate=2009-02-25 | format= | publisher=Government of Saskatchewan | date= 1997-2007) }} </ref> The Hudson's Bay Trading Post site was replaced with Chapel Coulee, Metis village of Chapel Coulee, which was later where the NWMP established a post in 1879 and small detachment from Fort Walsh. In 1887, the detachment moved to the banks of the White Mud River the current location of Eastend, Sk as many of their concernts were alleviated, the whisky trade had ceased, the [[North-West Rebellion]] of 1885 was over, and [[Sitting Bull]], a [[Hunkpapa]] [[Lakota people|Lakota]] [[Sioux]] holy man surrendered to American forces and returned to the [[United States]] in 1881.<ref group="nb" name="WhiteMud">The White Mud River is currently known as the Frenchman River</ref><ref name="eastend"/><ref name="eastend"/>[[File:VCRedversHenryBuller.jpg|thumb|upright|Sir [[Redvers Buller]] ]]The [[town]] of [[Redvers, Saskatchewan|Redvers]], SK, along the Red Coat Trail, is named after [[General]] [[Redvers Buller|Sir Redvers Henry Buller]] [[Victoria Cross|VC]] [[Order of the Bath|GCB]] [[Order of St Michael and St George|GCMG]] (1839–1908).<ref name="Redvers">{{cite web | url=http://www.creda.sk.ca/redvers/index.htm | title=Town of Redvers | accessdate=2009-02-25 | publisher= Cornerstone Regional Economic Development Authority | date= 2003 updated 11/05/07 }} </ref><ref name="KOASK">{{cite web | url=http://koa.com/vacationideas/redcoat/saskatchewan.htm | title=KOA: Red Coat Trail - Saskatchewan | work=Kampgrounds of America, Inc | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= Travel Communications, Inc. | year= 2004 }} </ref><ref name="Century">{{cite web | url=http://www.members.shaw.ca/d_y_g/3centuryfarm.htm | title=Century Farm | work=William J. Milner | accessdate=2009-02-11 | format=Canada Copyright Registration No. 490341 | publisher= Travel Communications, Inc. | date= March 8, 2001 }} </ref><ref name="KOAMB">{{cite web | url=http://koa.com/vacationideas/redcoat/manitoba.htm | title=KOA: Red Coat Trail - Manitoba | work=Kampgrounds of America, Inc | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= Travel Communications, Inc. | year= 2004 }} </ref> The Boundary Commission Trail is an earlier route used from Winnipeg for travel east.<ref name="MHS">{{cite web |last=MacDonald |first= Graham | url=http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/mb_history/19/boundarycommissiontrail.shtml | title=Manitoba History: The Boundary Commission Trail and the North-West Mounted Police: A Review of Site Development Progress | work=Manitoba History, Number 19, Spring 1990 | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= Manitoba Historical Society | date= 2002-2009 }} </ref><ref name="ATRed Coat Trail">{{cite web |last= Dean |first= Mike & Robin | url=http://www.turtleandtoad.com/CrossCanada/Album%20Pages/Maps/Redcoat%20Trail.htm | title=Map - Redcoat Trail | work=Along the Red Coat Trail | accessdate=2009-02-11 | publisher= | year= 2002 }} </ref>
